question.title: Run a Gradle build on one machine and use it on another machine that doesn't have internet access. How to copy gradle cache to another machine
question.body: I have a Gradle project that uses several plugins, which complicates things. I would like to build the project in such a way that, after moving the project files, built JARs, etc., to a machine without internet access or access to our local Artifactory, the project can still be built.

answers.body:
This thread helped me solve it:
Copying the Gradle cache to another machine

✅ Steps to make a Gradle project buildable offline on another machine:

  1. On a machine with internet access, run the following command in the root of your project:

    bash  gradlew.bat --build-cache --gradle-user-home ".\local-gradle" build --refresh-dependencies

    This ensures that all dependencies and plugin artifacts are downloaded into the local-gradle directory.

  2. Copy the entire project to the offline machine, including:

    • Source code

    • .gradle folder (if present)

    • .\local-gradle directory - this dirrecroy will contain cache

  3. On the offline machine, run this command from the root of the project:

    bash gradlew.bat build --gradle-user-home ".\local-gradle" --offline

⚠️ Important:

Make sure that the absolute folder path of the project on the offline machine is exactly the same as it was on the online machine.
For example, if the project was at:

C:\Workspaces\MyGradleProject

on Machine A (online), it must be placed in:

C:\Workspaces\MyGradleProject

on Machine B (offline).

Gradle appears to store some path-dependent metadata in its caches, so preserving the same folder structure is critical.
